block.p: Violence erupted in a Soviet republic. Moscow reported that at least 40 people had been killed in three days of ethnic rioting and Soviet troop countermeasures in the Central Asian republic of Kirghizia.

Violence erupted in a Soviet republic. Moscow reported that at least 40 people had been killed in three days of ethnic rioting and Soviet troop countermeasures in the Central Asian republic of Kirghizia.

Violence erupted in a Soviet republic. Moscow reported that at least 40 people had been killed in three days of ethnic rioting and Soviet troop countermeasures in the Central Asian republic of Kirghizia.

Nuclear plants in Eastern Europe fall far short of Western safety standards and in many cases should be radically modified or closed, West European scientists who inspected the reactors have concluded.

The man who ruled Czechoslovakia as Communist Party chief for two years until the party was overthrown last November was seized for interrogation on ''criminal offenses,'' including his role in the Soviet-led invasion in 1968.
Baker seeks Europe security group shift
Interpreters: hours of tedium and moments of precision
Soviets to repay lend-lease after a trade accord
News analysis: The historic meeting between President Gorbachev and President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea has been interpreted very differently by the two leaders.
China may sell chemicals to Libya that can be used to make poison gas, according to intelligence reports received by the U.S., Bush Administration officials said.
Justice agency warned on inquiry of loans to Iraq
A Gandhi crusades against a befouled India
Leader of Liberia refusing to quit
Guerrilla hideout is raided in Lima
Medellin journal: Savagery is the habit in cocaine capital

California's tax revolt has faded. A decade after they led a revolt against taxes and spending, voters approved higher gasoline taxes, a looser state spending limit and more than four billion dollars in bond issues.

The former Mayor of San Francisco, Dianne Feinstein, emerged from the primary not only as the Democratic nominee for governor of California but also as a charismatic centrist figure who may appeal to wayward Democrats and independents.
Each side says primaries prove strength on abortion

A plan for reducing military spending may be offered by the Bush Administration. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said he would prepare a study showing the policy effects of a 25 percent cut in troops, ships and air wings over five years.
The export of dangerous pesticides would be banned under legislation approved by the Senate Agriculture Committee. A similar proposal is pending in the House.
Kemp urges tightened F.H.A. insurance program
Jackson urges Barry to seek plea agreement
Washington Talk: Barney Frank isn't yet done for
The woman who committed suicide with a doctor's help after learning she had Alzheimer's disease had been at the center of a struggle by her family to keep her from killing herself.
Physician fulfills a goal: aiding a suicide
Diagnosis of Alzheimer's is no matter of certainty

A feud over the Missouri River has ended up in court. After nearly three years of drought in the upper basin states, only a season of plentiful rain across the river's western watershed can resolve interstate tensions.
Group says pollution fight won't hurt economy
Donations in U.S. climb, but worries linger
Federal judge rules rap album is obscene
From Voyager 1, a space snapshot of six planets
Shuttle must go to repair hangar

Donald J. Trump's three casinos in Atlantic City must supply the cash he needs to keep his sprawling empire going. But restoring the strength of his once-lucrative gaming houses will require management skills that Mr. Trump has yet to demonstrate.
A church treasurer who disappeared from Suffern, N.Y., in 1982 with $267,000 in church funds may have been found in Taos, N.M. He was spotted by a parishioner from the church.
A mandatory drug-testing policy adopted by the New York City Transit Authority in the mid-1980's for all job applicants and employees was declared unconstitutional by a Federal judge in Manhattan.
M.T.A. to run TV ads to gain subway riders

Albany was dealt another setback. A major credit agency lowered New York State's long-term credit rating one notch. The move comes three weeks after the state adopted a budget that its political leaders insisted was sound.

The ruling on New Jersey school aid prompted the Florio administration and the State Legislature to tailor the Governor's proposals on how the state raises and spends money to conform to the court decision.

Soil contaminated with radium will be removed from around and under as many as 400 houses in the New Jersey communities of Glen Ridge, Montclair and West Orange. Federal officials said they would spend more than $250 million on the project.
Brooklyn judge drops charge against grocer
New charge barred in Howard Beach retrial
Murder suspect almost walks out of court in Queens
At the Bronx Zoo, a damsel in distress is rescued
The manager of the New York Yankees was dismissed. Bucky Dent was replaced by Carl (Stump) Merrill, a longtime Yankee employee and the manager this season at the baseball team's Columbus affiliate.
Soccer: U.S. braces for rough stuff
The class of '90 looks ahead to family life
When Karan handles it, fur can look like silk
Pregnant women can gain more and skip vitamins
New findings tie cut in smoking to drop in heart disease
Meeting skin problems head-on in the summertime
A search to bar retardation in a new generation

Legislators rebuff extension on arts panel
